comments:
Hi folks, I think I finally discovered the root cause of the dreadful startup bug ("thread
"Worker-X" timed out waiting (5000ms) for thread "Worker-Y" to finish starting bundle
"org.eclipse.mylar.tasks.ui").

Warning: this is a very long bug... In fact there are
a set of bugs working together to make this happen (or not, according to the situation;
explanation bellow):

1 - Mylar plugins are doing expensive operations on Bundle.start():

I
see that tasks.ui plugin do many heavy-weight operations like reading the tasklist (which
involves XML parsing) on plugin start() method.

This type of operation must be made
on a background job because the platform has a timeout of 5 seconds for each plugin initialization.
The BundleActivator.start() javadoc explicitly says that this method MUST return quickly.

2
- Mylar plugins are doing expensive operations on Display.asyncExec():

Taking a quick
look, I see that at least context.ui, tasks.ui and mylar.team invoke Display.asyncExec()
{ [long-chain-of-method-calls] }.

The problem here is that asyncExec() forces the Runnable
to be executed on UI thread. If the Runnable takes much time to complete, this causes
UI to freeze. Probably this is the cause of UI freeze on Eclipse initialization I see.

The
worst case here is on tasks.ui. Instead of simply wrapping a code block inside asyncExec(),
we must track down the call stack and identify what methods requires to be executed on
UI thread, and wrap just them with asyncExec.

3 - There is a circular dependency between
context.core and tasks.ui:

This is the worst bug. Tasks UI depends on context.core
== OK. However, there is a "involuntary" dependency of context core on tasks UI, because
tasks UI provides a context store extension, so context core activation triggers tasks
UI activation while loading context store extensions, and vice-versa.

I think the easiest
way to fix this is to move the filesystem-based context store implementation to its own
plugin like I suggested on bug#160356 (I'm suposing that the filesystem context store
does not have any dependency on tasks UI classes).

This way, this new plugin (let's
call it "context.filesystem.store") would depend only on context.core. Context core activation
would only trigger context.filesystem.core activation. Tasks UI activation would trigger
context.core and so on.

Conclusion: there is a lot of problems contributing to make
this bug happen sometimes.

Sometimes, depending on VM classloading policy, and because
of busy BundleActivator.start() implementations, bug (1) can be triggered causing the
plugin init timeout.

Most times, bug (2) is causing bug (3) to NOT happen. I suppose
that asyncExec() would be masquerading the circular dependency, otherwise tasks UI would
trigger context core activation, which would trigger tasks UI, and so on. Probably the
"trigger" code would be inside a asyncExec() block, so it is scheduled to run on UI thread,
letting the plugin complete initialization.

However, on some VMs/OSs the thread policy
can be different, making the deadlock/plugin timeout happen.

Taking a quick look at
my bug list, I can remember strong candidates for being dups of this:

- bug#159706
- mylar fails to start on BEA jrockit VM
- bug#167320 - More startup errors after upgrading
to 1.0.0 test

To investigate:

- bug#167639 - 1.0 Errors on Startup.
- all bugs
containing "thread "Worker-X" timed out waiting (5000ms) for thread "Worker-Y" to finish
starting bundle blablabla" on stack trace.

So, fixing these 3 problems would end the
timeout problems.

Thanks for excellent analysis Willian, I think that you got the nail on the head.  We haven't seen this problem for a while, so I'm still wondering what triggers it (e.g. large number of plug-ins activating, very slow machine or pinned CPU).  Our previous laziness improvements made it better but did not solve it (1), and without making huge changes we will still some eagerness to ensure that all externalizers are loaded.  But I will definitely plan to do (3) for 1.0.1 to address this, and hope to make some improvements on the others.

Yes, fixing (3) is relatively low-risk and easy for 1.0.1 and would handle the worst case.

We'll still probably see some (1) cases occurring, but the changes needed to fix (1) and (2) are very risk to do in a so short iteration like 1.0.1.

We can revisit this on 2.x stream, since these are performance bugs too.

I tested various scenarios of (1) and (2) by adding a 30s sleep to both the start() and the asyncExec in the start method of the TasksUiPlugin.  Neither of those caused this failure and resulted in a very slow, but correct startup on both Sun and BEA VMs for both 3.3 and 3.2.  So I think that the underlying cause is (3), and the underlying problem is related to Platform bug 5875.  I believe that our circular dependency is correct, but the circular class loading can time out as described on that bug.

Willian: we can not simply move this extension point to another plug-in because the location of the context store is a preference that comes from the TasksUiPlugin.  And the Task List has to be loaded completely before any mylar.tasks.ui view or editor can show tasks, and note that the workbench restores editors on startup.  These and other issues related to walking this fine line between loading what we need eagerly (e.g. connectors) and deferring everything else to be loaded lazily is what has made this so tricky.  What I have done for 1.0.1 is to break the circularity by removing the extension point based way of specifying the context store, and instead having TasksUiPlugin.start set it explicitly in the code.  Since I can not reproduce this, I tested with a full Callisto install and did not see any problems.

Nathan and others seeing this problem: could you please verify by installing the 1.0.0.v20061219-1530 build from one of the following update sites?  Make sure to use "Search for new features" when updating.

  download.eclipse.org/technology/mylar/update-site/test/e3.2
  download.eclipse.org/technology/mylar/update-site/test/e3.3
If this is still happening for anyone with the builds linked above please reopen the bug.  It would be helpful if someone experiencing this bug could verify with the latest built.

I updated to the developer build using the link provided.  This changed the behavior slightly.  I no longer get the errors in the error log when Eclipse is starting up.  However, as far as I can tell, I get all the same errors the first time I try to open task.

The version is 1.0.0.v20061219-1530.

I'm not sure if it's possible for the same errors to happen after startup, so these might be related, or might be something else.  Could you clear your error log, restart, and then attach the full log to this bug after trying to open a task (assuming it contains errors)?  Also include a note on what kind of task you are trying to open.

I think this is not totally fixed yet. I got this with Eclipse 3.3 M4 + Mylar 1.0.1.

The result on this case was that the TaskList view wasn't loaded. The workaround is to restart Eclipse.

Mouse wheel is not so bad. Dragging a scroll bar is much worse...

Willian: could you please create a new bug for this?  The "State change in progress" message and location of the failure is different than what we were seeing previously, and resolving this may be as simple as ensuring that the progress bar and related Task List UI initialization happen lazily.

 (In reply to comment #18)
> Mouse wheel is not so bad. Dragging a scroll bar is much worse...

Yup.  Improving the way that stack traces are presented is bug 166402 (e.g. folding all but top few frames) and that's probably the better approach than trying to work around the performance profile of the form editor when the forms get huge.  For now I think it is best to paste in stack traces if they're not a full dump but either partial or hand edited.  That way we still get hyperlinking.  For full dumps with multiple traces attaching seems best.

Willian: it looks like you have found a bug that's different than that given by the description here, because it has to do with the fact that the MylarTeamPlugin reads extensions during it's start method.  What I have done to fix that is move the extension point reading into the asyncExec of MylarTeam.Plugin.start(..), which will prevent the startup concurrency.  These extension points do need to be initialized on the that plug-in's start method because they need to eagerly update the state of the change sets.  I can give you a dev build to try this out, what version of Eclipse are you running?  Fyi, I'm merging this change back into the 1.0 streams.

(In reply to comment #37)
> MylarTeamPlugin reads extensions during it's start method.  What I have done to
> fix that is move the extension point reading into the asyncExec of
> MylarTeam.Plugin.start(..), which will prevent the startup concurrency.  

Hmm... those asyncExecs() on startup don't look good for me. The problem is that removing them would take a lot of refactoring. If you have interest I can take a look when I have time.

> because they need to eagerly update the state of the change sets.  I can give
> you a dev build to try this out, what version of Eclipse are you running?  Fyi,
> I'm merging this change back into the 1.0 streams.
> 

For now, I'm using Eclipse 3.2.1, but I intend to switch to 3.3 as soon as M5 or perhaps M6 is released.

Willian: We use the asyncExecs(..) for the cases where we need the plug-in to do stuff at startup, i.e. where the preferred lazily initialization of extension points (or other plug-in state) does not work, but where the initializaiton should not hold up the initialization of the workbench (or causes problems when it does, as with the class loading bug).  In the case of the team provider, not doing this at startup would mean that the change sets would not be probably updated to contain the Mylar elements, since we have to do some tricks to convert the existing change sets that Eclipse supports into the Mylar context change sets.  But if you do encounter ways to improve on the initialization, please do post the ideas.

Regarding builds, we'll post a 3.2 dev build either this or next Friday.
